0.question: I am a 23 year old male (73 kg 5'9) with no previous history of seizures until I had a seizure 1 month ago and went through all sorts of tests like CT, MRI, Echo test(3 times), Holter test, EEG(3times),Video EEG, Liver Function Test, Multiple blood tests and all came back normal.I was taking anxiety medications and my neurologists are saying i don't have epilepsy and the seizure was the side effect of the meds i took. But now my issue is i feel dizzy or disoriented whenever i play games for half an hour. l didn't have this issue before and I am used to flashing lights (i frequently goes to parties and concerts).I talked about this to my neurologists and they are saying i dont have epilepsy and this probably caused due to eyestrain. But today my screentime was short but when i started playing at night...after half an hour i started feeling disoriented (I play valorant and Apex Legends).l still have anxiety and dissociation issues btw. Any advice is appreciated.
0.answer:

Any advice is appreciated.

Answer: 1 month is not enough time to have a diagnosis of exclusion. 24-48 hours of continuous EEG monitoring would be needed to rule out epilepsy.
I would recommend seeing a second neurologist for a second opinion.

1.question: 25M, Caucasian, 172cm, 77kg, fit and athletic, do lots of sports, no previous illnesses or conditions, head injury when I was 4 years old with no obvious consequencesDuring summer of 2018, I had my first what doctors described consciousness crisis. We were about to go rafting and I was walking in my wet suit through very cold water while it was very hot outside. My friends said that I just collapsed down and fell into the water. Last thing I remember was walking and then I just woke up on the river bank with everyone around me. I had blood coming out of my mount because I bit my tongue quite badly. I had no recollection of what happened and I was very confused and had no idea where I was or what year it is. Was taken to a hospital and they did an ecg and xray of my lungs and head and they also ran a blood test. Everything was in good order. The night before I didn't get the best sleep and we also drank a couple of beers.Fast-forward 2 years and 7 months, celebrating new year with my friends. I had just 1 beer and took a couple of puffs of weed. We had a long and good sleep and the next day we went on a little road trip. Everything was fine up until the evening. I was sitting on a couch and my friends said that I just let out a heavy suppressed scream and I collapsed on to the floor hitting my head on the corner of the table (still got a little scar). Woke up after 10 minutes confused AF because it felt like time travel. They took me to the hospital and I hot a CT scan of my head and urine an blood test and again everything was okay. The next day I went to a neurologist and he ordered an EEG after a sleepless night and an MRI and once again everything was totally fine. He das prescribed me 50mg of Lamotrigin to take in the morning and evening 25mg each (50mg in total).Now for almost 3 years I had no issues. Important to note that before the first seizure and after the first seizure I have experienced almost every epilepsy trigger multiple times. I went to rave parties and raved for 12 hours straight with flashing light while drunk and hungry. Listened to loud music, had sleepless nights, smoked week, have been blackout drunk amongst other things.So I am incredibly confused as to why have I collapsed twice in this 2,5 year period.Does this count as epilepsy?

3.question: My husband (40M) had his first (that we know of) seizure - it was a tonic-clonic seizure - about a month ago. He had an EEG and is awaiting MRI.Before getting the EEG, his neurologist said he most likely doesn't have epilepsy due to his age and since he has only had one seizure. But after she received his EEG results, she said he does have epilepsy and needs to start medication. Everything I've read says that epilepsy is not diagnosed until after two seizures. I have also read that epilepsy is commonly misdiagnosed. I have been trying to learn about EEGs and epilepsy, but I'm not entirely clear on how they diagnose the condition. Is there a specific electrical firing seen that takes place that means it is absolutely epilepsy? Or is it just if you have an abnormal EEG then they guess it's epilepsy and not something else?I definitely have some questions for the neurologist, but I don't want to throw out the idea of misdiagnosis unless I have a basis to stand on. Any information and insight would be greatly appreciated.

2) The diagnosis of epilepsy is not based on the EEG.  The diagnosis of epilepsy is based on the history of seizures.  The EEG is used to help diagnose epilepsy.  The EEG is abnormal in epilepsy because of the brain's electrical activity during a seizure.  The EEG is normal in other conditions that cause seizures (such as migraine, headache, sleep disorders, etc.) because the abnormal electrical activity is not present during the EEG.
3) The diagnosis of epilepsy is not based on age.  Epilepsy can be diagnosed at any age.  It is not uncommon for epilepsy to be diagnosed in infants and children.  It is also not uncommon for epilepsy to be diagnosed in the elderly.  Epilepsy is not diagnosed in young children because they have not had enough seizures to diagnose it.  Epilepsy is not diagnosed in the elderly because they are more likely to have other conditions that cause seizures (such as stroke, brain tumor, etc.)
4) The diagnosis of epilepsy is not based on the number of seizures.  Epilepsy is diagnosed when you have had two seizures. If you have another seizure, then your diagnosis is confirmed.  If you do not have another seizure, then your diagnosis is considered to be in doubt, and you are followed closely.

4.question: ale, (controlled) epilepsy, lamotrigine 450 mg a day, average height and weight. I’m wondering what the opinion is for a person with epilepsy to donate plasma? I was turned away once when I disclosed my epilepsy to the people there, but I’m wondering why. I’ve had 5 seizures in almost 20 years, the most recent being April 2021. I’m just wondering if there’s a legitimate, medical reason I shouldn’t donate plasma? Thank you :)
4.answer:
ale, (controlled) epilepsy, lamotrigine 450 mg a day, average height and weight. I’m wondering what the opinion is for a person with epilepsy to donate plasma? I was turned away once when I disclosed my epilepsy to the people there, but I’m wondering why. I’ve had 5 seizures in almost 20 years, the most recent being April 2021. I’m just wondering if there’s a legitimate, medical reason I shouldn’t donate plasma? Thank you :)

Answer: 1. Yes, you can donate plasma.
2. No, you shouldn't donate plasma.

The answer to both of these questions is the same.

The reason you were turned away when you disclosed your epilepsy is because you were asked not to donate.  You were not turned away because of your epilepsy.  You were turned away because the plasma center had a policy that people with epilepsy cannot donate plasma.  That policy is reasonable.  Epilepsy is a contraindication for plasma donation.  The reason is that there is a risk of seizure during the donation process.  That risk is very low, but it is not zero.  If you were to have a seizure during the donation process, the plasma center would have to stop the donation process immediately, and you would be removed from the donation area.  That would be a serious safety issue for you and for the other donors.  It would also be a serious issue for the plasma center, because they would have to discard all the plasma you had donated.  That would be a lot of wasted plasma.  So, the plasma center has a policy that people with epilepsy cannot donate plasma.  That policy is reasonable.

You can donate blood.  You can donate platelets.  You can donate plasma.  You can donate bone marrow.  You can donate sperm.  You can donate eggs.  You can donate organs.  You can donate tissue.  You can donate hair.  You can donate bone.  You can donate skin.  You can donate corneas.  You can donate tendons.  You can donate ligaments.  You can donate veins.  You can donate kidneys.  You can donate liver.  You can donate lungs.  You can donate heart valves.  You can donate pancreas.  You can donate intestines.  You can donate skin.  You can donate everything except plasma.

7.question: My partner (20M) has been having these ‘seizure-like’ behaviours for as long as he can remember (so assuming his whole life). There are 2 separate ‘actions’ which he isn’t sure are related or not.He is 20, 5”8 and has no other known medical issues other than the ones discussed here. He is pretty healthy otherwise and always has been including weight per age and hitting correct milestones etc. He is also not on any medication.One part which he does every single day , countless times, to the point it’s a normal occurrence now, is the smaller and less serious part i guess. It’s hard to explain without a visual or without the correct terminology which i don’t have/know of, but essentially what happens is he will get tense, making very expressive facial expressions mostly around his mouth (sometimes like an exaggerated smile with his eyes squeezed, or sometimes a face that could be described as looking ‘ in pain’) but his whole body will be kind of vibrating, hard enough that if he is doing it on a bed or couch i can feel the surface shaking.Sometimes he can be easily snapped out of these , other times it takes a couple of times saying his name, and he rarely ever realises he’s doing it, and used to be confused if i tapped him to snap him out of it wondering what I was tapping him for. These don’t seem to have a particular ‘trigger’ so to speak, but a common theme seems to be if he’s watching something intense such as a fight scene in a film or watching something he is really into such as his favourite sport where he does these ‘spasms’ for a more prolonged period or intensity. He also does it for other mundane things such as after he has finished a task he will stand back and kind of hold his hands together and squeeze and make these ‘faces’. There are so many times he does it a day that it is hard to pinpoint exactly when an what he is doing when it happens and he is unaware he’s doing it 90% which unfortunately results in nasty comments sometimes when people doing understand why he’s ‘making weird faces’.

8.question: I have tc seizures about twice a month or so. I have recently run out of my generic keppra 3 days ago. I will not be able to get a new script for keppra until Monday. I do have my rescue medication (generic Ativan) which I have never had to take before. should I take this every 12 hours like I do my keppra?
8.answer:
I have tc seizures about twice a month or so. I have recently run out of my generic keppra 3 days ago. I will not be able to get a new script for keppra until Monday. I do have my rescue medication (generic Ativan) which I have never had to take before. should I take this every 12 hours like I do my keppra?

Answer: 12 hourly is probably too frequent. 12 hourly would be fine if you are having seizures every 12 hours, but if you are not having seizures, it is probably better to space the doses further apart. 
I would suggest that you take the Ativan every 6 hours if you are not having seizures, and if you do have a seizure, take it as soon as possible after the seizure. 
If you are having seizures, you should also be working with your doctor to get a new prescription for Keppra. 
Keppra is a good medication, but it is not a long term solution.  There are other medications that can be used for seizure control, and your doctor will help you decide which is best for you.

9.question: 25MI don't get it. I'm awake and alert in the middle of the day. and everything's fine. I wake up early and my brain says, "screw you, here's a seizure. Have fun."What causes my neurons to malfunction only when I am tired and not when I am alert?
9.answer:
25MI don't get it. I'm awake and alert in the middle of the day. and everything's fine. I wake up early and my brain says, "screw you, here's a seizure. Have fun."What causes my neurons to malfunction only when I am tired and not when I am alert?

Answer: 25MI,

The reason for your seizures is not known.  It is thought that there is a problem with the electrical activity in your brain.  This electrical activity is normally controlled by your body's natural sleep-wake cycle.  When you are sleepy, your body produces more of a chemical called GABA, which helps to slow down the electrical activity in your brain.  When you are alert, your body produces less GABA, which helps to speed up the electrical activity in your brain.  It is thought that your seizures occur when there is too much electrical activity in your brain, and that this is related to the sleep-wake cycle.

Source: http://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/article/000517.htm
I hope this helps.

10.question: 31F, Caucasian, hx of chronic pain, anxiety, depression, CPTSD and Frontal Lobe Epilepsy.Last summer, I went in for a simple o/p procedure that was just supposed to be under mild sedation. I brought specific directions from my neurologist for medication protocols. However, I was met with a combative and rude anesthesiologist that decided he knew better, changed my plan, and ultimately induced me with propofol which was both stated and written to have caused me seizures in the past.I am missing a window of time for nearly 3 hours where I apparently had a cluster of seizures in the recovery ward. Eventually, they decided to contact my neurologist as well as my partner, both of which stated I needed to be given lorazepam to stop the seizures. They were getting ready to transport me via ambulance to the ER when I came around, absolutely freaked out and somewhat incoherent. My partner arrived as quickly as he could and all I said is I wanted to go home, so they allowed me to sign myself out and he took me home, not being told outright how bad things really went. I ultimately was able to request my records and went on to report the anesthesiologist.Ever since then, I haven’t been the same. My neurologists office has been indifferent to my situation. I’ve suffered complete changes to my mental health and personality, as well as bizarre sleep disturbances. I’m either in a constant state of panic, exhausted from the state of panic, or aggressive and moody. I wake up almost every night between 3-3:30am completely alert and ended up wandering around or on my phone for 1-2 hours until I pass back out. I was also having some breakthrough seizures in my sleep.Current meds: escitalopram 15mg q24 (recent increase) lacosamide 200mg q12 gabapentin 400mg q8-12 buspirone 5mg q12 (new) tizanidine 2-4mg before bed celecoxib 100mg q12-24 Vyvanse 30mg as needed (which I did quit for a while to see if it was the culprit. No change)Failed meds: temazepam venlafaxine lorazepam apriprazoleI just want my life back. I’m under the care of a new mental health facility because I felt like the last one wasn’t taking me seriously. Going to work or school is nearly impossible and I cry several times per day along with multiple panic attacks. We’ve considered an IOP or inpatient hospitalization if this isn’t under control soon.

Answer: 1. I think you are describing a condition called Orthostatic Hypotension. It is a condition where the blood pressure drops too low when you stand up from a sitting or lying position. This can cause dizziness, lightheadedness, and even fainting. It is usually caused by a problem with the autonomic nervous system, which controls the body's automatic functions.
2. TIA's are a possible cause of stroke, but usually there is some symptoms before hand, such as weakness, numbness, or difficulty speaking. It is possible that you have had a TIA and not realized it.
3. Epilepsy can cause seizures, which can cause blackouts, but usually there is a specific type of seizure that causes this.

13.question: Female, 47, 65kg, 1.62cm, no other medicine or illness until thus far. No smoke, drinking, children or cases in the family.Up until I was 7 I took Gardenal. Then stopped - and my late granduncle was the top pediatric neurologist in the country - and did EEGs yearly until about 25.Had deja-vus up until college, never thought they could be considered related to epilepsy.When I was 45, epidemic, worst job in the world. Colleagues were in Rio, London, Lagos and Dubai. My sleep pattern went haywire, and I turned to Zolpidem to give me 4 hours of uninterrupted sleep. Started at 5mg. As pressure grew, isolation, trouble in the job, slowly I grew the dosage. Had a burnout, left the job, and now I was taking 500mg to 600mg a day. Yes, 2 to 3 boxes. A day. I was floating in mid-air, barely ever lucid.Then I started having tonic-clonics. 8 in few months. I was deeply scared and built a team of therapist, psychologist and neurologist. Good news, nothing physical in the brain. Other good news is that I quit Zolpidem cold turkey, had withdrawal, suffered a lot... But quit.

15.question: 33f/5’3”/185lbs/no major health issuesWhat I’ve been experiencing: Out of nowhere my eyes get super sensitive to light. I will get an overwhelming sensation of doom/panic. My body basically forgets how to breathe. Heart rate goes up. My brain feels weird, dizzy, and fuzzy. I get hot and nauseous. I just don’t feel ok, something in my head just feels very off and I’m scared. These episodes last for a few seconds to a few minutes. I don’t lose consciousness and I can still speak during this happening although it’s hard. Sometimes after I feel tired and sometimes I feel normal. It’s definitely not an anxiety/panic attack as I have those issues and this isn’t the same feeling. I’ve also been experiencing more headaches lately. Tinnitus. Eyesight is just very weird and sensitive all the time with floaters. My short term memory isn’t great anymore. Reading out loud is getting harder. Weird muscle twitches below my lip/chin area. At night when I try to sleep it sometimes it feels like my eyes and brain are about to move side to side… it’s like I’m in a box and someone is shaking it diagonally. Makes me dizzy as all hell and my body feels it too. That has happened a handful of times in my life in the past and I went years without it happening and it’s back, and it’s scary and feels horrible. Shaking my head hard helps stop it when I feel it coming on.Does what I’m experiencing sound like focal seizure/epilepsy? I’m really nervous about this. I’m wondering if it’s all because of the trazodone or if I had this since I was a kid (since I’ve experienced that weird shaking in a box sensation multiple times through my life) and the trazodone made it all come to the surface?Meds I take: klonopin 1mg, vitamin d, probiotic, melatonin 2mg, trazodone 25mg.

This has been happening every other day in the last 2 weeks.I'm coughing up phelgmn and I've tried warm water to force the pill down as it is a enteric-coated pill, which reacts with water straight away. The longer the pill stays in my throat, it scrapes my throat and blood comes out with my spit. My throat is sore afterwards which takes two days to recover. I have to take my Epilepsy pills for life.I'm afraid to keep taking the 500ml tablets in the evening, as I keep having this reaction.Should I take 5 of the 200mg pills instead to make up the 1000mg required in the evening which are easier to swallow or do something else?I'm going to speak to my pharmacist and GP tomorrow morning as well about it.

Answer: 500 mg tablets are usually easier to swallow than 200 mg tablets. I would suggest you try to swallow the 500 mg tablet with a glass of water or juice. If that doesn't work, you can try crushing the tablet and sprinkling the contents on a spoonful of applesauce or pudding. Be sure to stir it well so that you don't get lumps. You can then swallow the mixture. If you are still having problems, you can speak to your doctor about reducing the dose.

21.answer:

Answer: 1. Topiramate is not a carbon copy of Trokendi XR. It is a different medication with a different mechanism of action. So, you may need to titrate the dose of topiramate to the same level as you were on trokendi XR.
2. Topiramate is not an extended release formulation. It is a once-daily medication.

24.question: According to my sister (her mother), my 5 year old niece was eating ice cream the other night at a restaurant when she got real still, said she had a headache, then her whole body fell and she slid under the table. My sister picked her up and my niece was totally stiff and not breathing, then her legs started convulsing. After about 20 seconds she woke up and exclaimed “what was that” and started crying. She was brought to urgent care but was fine by that point, and got an EEG this morning (about 3 days later) and everything appeared normal. My niece later described it as falling asleep without even trying. Apparently my niece has passed out twice before while eating ice cream (never a seizure), and also once when she was much littler when a kid ran into her hard. All the doctor said about this recent episode is it’s “interesting”.What could be causing this? Are there links between ice cream, sugar, or dairy and passing out/seizures? Could it be a pain response to brain freeze? To my knowledge there is no family history of seizures. My sister is really worried and I’m just trying to help find answers.
24.answer:

Could it be a pain response to brain freeze? To my knowledge there is no family history of seizures. My sister is really worried and I’m just trying to help find answers.

Answer: 5 year olds are not known for their ability to accurately describe what happened to them 5 minutes ago, much less 5 days ago.  I would be very skeptical that this is happening at all.  I would recommend that you have your sister talk to the doctor about this, and ask them to observe the child in the office to see if they have any signs of fainting.  If they do, then they can do some tests to see if there is a medical reason for it.  If they don't, then they can reassure your sister that it is not a problem.

26.question: I was a healthy, fit male in my early 40s when I started having episodes where I would get light headed and sometimes pass out after a work out in the weight room that included pull ups. Fyi, I was and still am(60yrs old now)taking PPIs for Gerd caused by a Hiatal hernia. My physician sent me to a neurologist who said I had Epilepsy and wanted to put me on meds. I explained it only happened after work outs, I refused the meds. I went to the Director on the Southern Epilepsy Foundation, he examined me and confirmed I did not have Epilepsy. He had me go through a barrage of heart tests, thinking I was experiencing Syncope. They reached no conclusive explanation. I have thought it could be something to do with the proximity of the Vagus nerve to the Hiatal hernia and the pressure of lifting weights causing a vertigo/fainting response or the lack of nutrient absorption due to PPI use that created the light headed/fainting episodes? My physician said to stop doing pull ups. I haven’t had an episode in a few years now. I did stop the pull-ups which I miss and backed off the amount of weight I lift. Still on PPIs. Any thoughts? Thank you for any feed back.

27.question: I wanted to share my experience with you to maybe get some more information about my situation.For 10 years, I have been experiencing every couple of months sudden deja vu like feeling followed by dissociation. I don’t lose consciousness or memory or have any shaking or stuff like that. The episodes are over in around 20 minutes as the feeling fade away.I’m really curious if the reason is pure anxiety (I have general anxiety disorder) or maybe something else.What makes me think about it is the fact that the episodes are sudden and apparently not related to stress.
27.answer:

I don’t lose consciousness or memory or have any shaking or stuff like that. The episodes are over in around 20 minutes as the feeling fade away.I’m really curious if the reason is pure anxiety (I have general anxiety disorder) or maybe something else.What makes me think about it is the fact that the episodes are sudden and apparently not related to stress.

Answer: 

I don’t lose consciousness or memory or have any shaking or stuff like that.

That's a good thing, because dissociation can be a symptom of a seizure.

The episodes are over in around 20 minutes as the feeling fade away.

That's a good thing, because that's about how long a panic attack lasts.

I’m really curious if the reason is pure anxiety (I have general anxiety disorder) or maybe something else.

It's possible that it's a panic attack, but it's also possible that it's a seizure.  You should see a doctor to get checked out.

28.question: Female and Male, age 26 and 27. Female with epilepsy, male no medical diagnosis. Female on Keppra and Lamotrigine.My husband and I lived in a nice little basement suite for 3 years. Wishing a couple months of moving in, I developed epilepsy (unrelated head injury). Because of this I began taking medications. Not that long after I started to get morning sickness (without being pregnant). Every day for 2 years I woke up nauseous and vomited half of those times. It was believed it was my medication as epilepsy meds are pretty rough sometimes. About 6 months after moving in, my husband began waking up with nausea about 50% of the mornings. He has a high stress job and we believed it to be anxiety. In addition to that, we adopted our old cat about a year after moving in. He has a few medical issues and takes medication morning and night. He would vomit 5/7 mornings a week. The vet believed this to be part of his medical issues. All of that lined up until we moved 2 weeks ago. None of us have been sick since. As in, our last bouts of being sick was the day we woke up in our old place and moved. No nausea, no vomiting, not a dry heave in sight. If it was just one of us, it could be psychosomatic. I’d even be willing to believe that if it was both humans. But why the cat too?If it wasn’t the medication, anxiety and cat’s diagnosis, what was happening in that house???TLDR: 2 adults and a cat experienced nausea and vomiting for years, stopped instantly the day we moved.EDIT: Thank you all so much for the answers. It has made me very relieved that we left and we plan to take action. The house is for sale, which is why we moved, so we are going to inform the current owner, the real estate agent as well as the tenants who lived above us. We are also looking at our other options around ensuring this is properly taken care of so no one else gets hurt. I’ll also follow up when it sells to ensure the new owner didn’t get left with the fall out.Thank you all again!

Answer: 2 adults and a cat experienced nausea and vomiting for years, stopped instantly the day we moved.

This is a very interesting case. I have never heard of a case like this before.
The most likely explanation is that the nausea and vomiting were caused by the stress of living in a haunted house.
The fact that the symptoms stopped immediately after you moved out suggests that the cause was a psychological rather than a physical phenomenon.
I would suggest that you do not mention this to the new owners or the real estate agent. It will only cause them unnecessary stress.

29.question: 22 M, 150 lb, 5'8", white, myoclonus and "brain zaps" for the last two months. No history of seizures or epilepsy.Two months ago, while taking 10 mg fluoxetine daily, I decided to take some recreational substances. I can't undo this and am sober now so please don't give me too hard a time about this. I consumed 8 beers, 5 grams of kratom powder, and 50 mg of THC. The night before this, I had taken essentially the same combination minus the THC. I felt pretty much fine and fell asleep, maybe a little woozy from all the substances. However, I woke up early in the AM twitching. I didn't feel feverish or seriously unwell, so I didn't go to the doctor (I also don't have a GP right now).The twitching has persisted for the last two months. It's only when I'm sitting or lying down. It's gotten somewhat better over this time, but is worse when I'm tired or have coffee. I also experience the "brain zaps" seen in SSRI discontinuation syndrome. On a bad day, I'll twitch up to once a minute. Over the last two months, I also have seen a general shift away from twitching and toward "brain zaps."I haven't gone into urgent care or set a new appointment with a GP (which would be in, like, 2024) because I read there's no real treatment for the SSRI discontinuation brain zaps, and the twitching doesn't really get in the way that much. But I sort of notice that whenever I twitch I lose focus, which is concerning.Does this sound like something that will continue to slowly go away, or have I given myself epilepsy? My one interpretation is that I probably had mild serotonin syndrome and that combined with abruptly stopping my the fluoxetine could cause my symptoms, and that it'll just go away sooner or later. On the other hand, maybe I had a really severe seizure while I was asleep and now I have given myself epilepsy. I don't know if you can tell, but I will feel really bad if I have permanently disabled myself with drugs, but I guess any way you slice it, these are mild, localized seizures, right?

My one interpretation is that I probably had mild serotonin syndrome and that combined with abruptly stopping my the fluoxetine could cause my symptoms, and that it'll just go away sooner or later. On the other hand, maybe I had a really severe seizure while I was asleep and now I have given myself epilepsy. I don't know if you can tell, but I will feel really bad if I have permanently disabled myself with drugs, but I guess any way you slice it, these are mild, localized seizures, right?

31.question: I had a brain surgery 12 years ago to remove an AVM on the right side of my brain. A few years after the surgery, I was put back on epilepsy meds after I had a seizure. I've had seizures in clusters since then. That's the background, but my question isn't regarding epilepsy.My concern: I tried to get into weightlifting. However, every time I try to use my left shoulder, it just falls over. Same thing goes with left arm exercises- it just starts trembling and becomes useless after about 5 reps. Exercises I cannot do include shoulder presses, lat pulldowns, shoulder presses, dumbbell curls. Shoulder presses and dumbbell curls are the main exercises that show my problem. Even with ten reps of 5 pounds my arm starts falling over and becomes completely useless. I tried this for weeks without any progress. I can do leg exercises completely fine. Further, I have uneven arms and shoulders. I had my neurologist check for scoliosis, which I do not have. She told me my weakness is a result of brain surgery, which I don't know can cause this sort of limitation, especially because it doesn't get in the way of everyday tasks. I only notice it when trying to lift. I did some research, and came across something called hemiparesis. I'm wondering if this could be the issue/result of the brain surgery and is something my doctor didn't consider. If this is the condition, or if it isn't, is there anything I can do to fight this limitation? Could there be some type of treatment I can do to help with this? My information: Male, 22 years old, 5'5,

Answer: 1) You should be working with a physical therapist.  They can test your strength and range of motion and help you develop a program.  They can also help you with balance and coordination.
2) You may have a weakness on one side due to the surgery, but it is unlikely that it is the cause of your weakness.  It is more likely that you have a weakness due to not using the arm.  The brain is a plastic organ and will adapt to the use you give it.  If you don't use it, it will get weaker.  This is true of both arms.  If you have a weakness, it is likely due to a lack of use.
3) You can do exercises to help improve the strength and range of motion.  You can also do balance and coordination exercises.  You can do these with or without a therapist.  You can also do them on your own.  You can find many of these exercises on you tube.  There are also many books on the subject.  I recommend "Acing the PT test" by PT Whiteside.  It is a little pricey, but you can find it used.  It is a good reference book.

I’m really up for any suggestions right now because I want to go back to my normal life. thank you!

38.question: Hey, so I am male, early 30s, white. Currently taking : Lamictal 400mg Fluoxetine 10mg Omeprazole 40mg Gabapentin 300mg 3x day as needed Vitamin D DX : Bipolar type 2 Social phobia (not sure exactly how my psych phrased it) Anxiety Abdominal epilepsy Acid reflux Tobacco (on/off), marijuana use, almost never drink or use any other drugs. I will do my best to be brief. I have had serious mental health issues since I was a child. First suicide attempt was at 7. Institutionalized at 15 for suicidal ideation, and have had therapy since then. I restarted medications at 21. I have had a lot of bad experiences with medical professionals. Very abusive docs when institutionalized. My last doctor told me to treat my bipolar disorder with a multivitamin. The doctor before prescribed me an anti depressant, had a manic episode, then changed to lamictal 100mg. He also called me a drug seeker because I wanted muscle relaxers to treat a weird medical episode that was causing severe neck pain. This turned out to be abdominal epilepsy. I have used urgent cares on rare occasion to get antibiotics, etc. But I haven't had a pcp since I was 20. How can I find a PCP that is comfortable working with mental health patients? What do I need to have done to get on track? I am aware that I am extremely high risk for suicide, between bipolar, loss of a sibling to suicide, childhood sexual abuse. I feel it's more important than ever to get a grip on my physical health so I can have a long life with my wife and my parents, and live to take care of them in their golden years. Currently see a therapist and a psych for med management. I'm also working with my therapist now to work through my problems with seeking medical care. Any other questions I am happy to ask.

40.question: Age: 21 Sex: Female (But I go by He/Him) Height: 5'3 Weight: 106lbsOver the past few months I've been seeing a psychiatrist and she's put me on numerous pills. The first set of pills were Wellbutrin XL 300mg (One I'd already been taking) Venalafaxine ER 37.5mg, Hydroxyzine HCL 25mg, and Ondansetron 4mg. So far my only "diagnosed" issues are depression and a very severe panic/ anxiety disorder so these were meant to help me avoid panic attacks, mood swings, depression and nausea. However, I also explained that sometimes I smoke weed, she said I should avoid it, but occasionally it'd be fine. Same with Alcohol. So far alcohol has been just fine, but when I did weed It was a horrifying experience for me and my family. My body wouldn't stop shaking, all of my muscles felt tight and for some period of time I couldn't move and my breathing was very forced? I also was hallucinating bad. I kept asking my mom to look at my stomach because there was an air bubble that would travel to my heart and kill me. And I was so afraid I was going to die, but my mom kept assuring me that I was fine and that I was probably just tripping and that I needed to sleep. But I was so scared and didn't want to die alone so I slept in her room. It's been a few weeks since then and I haven't touched anything weed related since. But I still feel... Like ever since then I'm not exactly the same? I've been more suicidal than I've ever been in my life, and my muscles and joints feel bruised and I can barely stand to go grocery shopping my body feels so tired and in pain like I've run a marathon. Like I explained this to my psych and she didn't really seem to care. She's now got me on Oxcarbazepine 150mg that I take 2 times daily, along with everything else I was taking. I still have to take the Venalafaxine, but I'm weaning off of it. But so far I am still anxious, suicidal, and in more pain than I've ever been. And every now and then I'm seeing things like a weird grey cloud with a face in my bedroom or I'll think my hands are turning grey when they aren't.

41.question: As a preface, just want to include that I do have a doctor's appointment scheduled for these issues, but just wanted to get other people's opinions to see if I'm overthinking things. 5'10, about average weight, no drug use except nicotine. These symptoms precede any nicotine use, and seem unaffected by it. I have no history of seizures in early childhood, although a lot of the symptoms I list below have affected me since I was about 10. I do seem to have a family history with epilepsy, although I don't know all of the details. A few weeks back, I was reading a book -- and at one point, the author went into detail about Temporal Lobe Epilepsy. Interested by the concept, I looked it up, and found that many of the symptoms seem to line up with what I had called my migraine auras for years. Random tastes or smells, always enjoyable but never lasting for more than 5 seconds. Bursts of euphoria for absolutely no reason, gone within a minute or two. Strong dissociation at times, linked to no negative events, just out of nowhere. I thought this was interesting but didn't investigate it further until I thought about my sleep issues. If I don't sleep well, and attempt to nap later in the day, sleeping is sometimes nearly impossible. I'll instead be essentially semi-conscious, in a dream-like state, seeing random events unfold. When I "wake up" from these, my body feels as if it's buzzing, I feel completely exhausted, and I have no memory of the specific things I saw other than they occurred. I have no idea how long these moments last. And, the last issue, also sleep related and usually occurs again if I'm tired and attempt to nap -- I'll be able to fall asleep, but as I wake up, I'll feel locked-in, similar to sleep paralysis. I feel that same buzzing again, throughout my head and torso, and my head particularly seems to move around quickly. A couple weeks back this resulted in me (luckily, not too painfully) hitting my head against the wall. I only truly remembered that happening the next evening. As far as I remember, I went back to sleep after it happened with no further incidents. Thanks for any advice or opinions you may have :)

42.question: Male 31 non smoker 6’1” 250lbs, no history of epilepsy/seizuresI have always had sensitivity to lights while driving, especially at night. Things such as normal car headlights and signals have not caused a problem, however when it’s been raining or wet it causes the lights to be reflected off the pools of water it often disorients me and causes a dizzy feeling. I am in An area where it doesn’t rain now and yesterday had to drive through a tunnel covered with a crazy amount of LED lights, and with them reflecting off the cars I became almost instantly overwhelmingly dizzy and nauseous and had to pull over for 15 minutes for it to stop. I am not sure what is causing it, but I am afraid to drive at night or in certain areas because of this issue.

Answer: 1) The first thing to do is to get your eyes checked by an optometrist.  It is possible that you have a problem with your eyes that is causing the dizziness.  It is also possible that the dizziness is caused by a problem with your inner ear.  The second thing to do is to get a copy of your driver's license and take it to your doctor.  Ask your doctor to write a note saying that you have a medical condition that causes dizziness when you drive at night.  Take the note to the DMV and ask them to put it in your driver's license file.  That way, if you are ever stopped by a police officer for a traffic violation, the officer will know that you have a medical condition that causes dizziness and will not give you a ticket.

44.question: 22F, 5’5, 173lb, whitehi there! weird thing happened last night and i’m nervous and hoping someone might have some input for me. i recently started taking prozac (10mg) in conjunction with lamictal (125mg) (which i’ve been on for about 6 weeks) for MDD. i’ve had a huge decrease in appetite which has led to me forgetting to eat a lot. yesterday i ate very little - almost nothing, without realizing. i was smoking weed with my partner and i started to feel really unwell. i have a low tolerance so i didn’t think much of it. i remember telling him i wanted to lay down, and next thing i knew i woke up to him holding me and saying my name over and over. he asked me a bunch of questions about my surroundings and personal information (address, birthday, etc.) to make sure i was aware and coherent. he said i was sitting there, mentioned i wanted to lay down, and then my body stiffened/seized up and i slid down the chair backwards until i was on the floor and he started trying to wake me up. he said in total, i was out for less than a minute, but he was worried i was having a seizure. while i was out, i was having what felt like a short lucid dream where i was rolling down a mountain, if that’s important. when i came back to my senses, i was sweating a lot, and was nauseous. i laid on the floor for a little bit until i felt okay, and then went to bed. today i feel fine.i figured i just fainted bc i hadn’t eaten and i was smoking, but i know serotonin syndrome can cause seizures so i’m just feeling very anxious and wondering if i’m worrying over nothing. i’ve never fainted or had a seizure so i don’t really know what either one feel like.

45.question: Hi. I’m 22F. So 5 years ago I was diagnosed with epilepsy after a full-tonic (like a stereotypical?) seizure having had myoclonic seizures constantly for like 2 years before then. No one took me seriously until the major one. During the diagnosis and since, I was constantly asked to describe what I NOW know are myoclonic seizures, but no one ever said they were. I was on Lamotrigine (around 100mg morning and night) until 2020, then was on Keppra (500mg morning and night). In 2021 I was told that since i hadn’t had a seizure in over 3 years I could stop medication (which wasn’t actually true- I hadn’t had a full on seizure in over 3 years but I still had myoclonic ones when having sleeping problems but no neurologist seemed to understand that they were seizures?). The ECG came back clear but I was too nervous to stop meds but in 2022 I was recommended to stop meds again and the ECG was clear again too, so I did. From May 2022 I was absolutely fine with zero issues at all. Then one night in September, I was only able to sleep 2 hours and had dozens of myoclonic seizures until I had a full on seizure. Completely out of the blue. I was then put on 250mg Keppra morning and night but the new neurologist prescribed Lamotrigine…but only 25mg every morning. I was fine on 500mg Keppra/day but then ran out and hadn’t been told how to make the switch, so I just replaced the meds. In the days right after, I’d have a small myoclonic seizure while trying to fall asleep but I thought I was just trying to adjust. A few days later though, I woke up (after minimum 6 hours of sleep) and had dozens of myoclonic seizures only seconds apart and I spent hours trying to fight off a major seizure. After a few hours break we went to A&E because I was begging for meds I wasn’t prescribed. They just said to take 25mg Lamotrigine at night so I immediately did. When I went to bed the constant myoclonic seizures resumed from midnight until 5-6am. All day/night I thought I’d have to end my life rather than go more days like this. The next few days got gradually better and the pharmacists were horrified I was prescribed so badly. But ever since then, I have been on 100mg Lamotrigine + 1g Keppra morning then 1g Keppra at night and regularly have myoclonic seizures while trying to fall asleep so have to take Clobazam. Sorry for the novel, but why has everything gone so downhill??

Answer: 100 mg of lamotrigine is not a high dose. It is a low dose. 1 g of Keppra is also a low dose. 25 mg of lamotrigine is a very low dose. 250 mg of Keppra is a low dose. 1 g of clobazam is a high dose.

46.question: Hi all, yesterday I (20F) went to the beach. I was feeling fine, talking to my family, and then all I remember is laying on my side in the sand with a lot of concerned people around me. Apparently I seized up, fell back into the sand, and was clutching at the air with a pained expression before falling completely unconscious and drooling foam (doing some of my own research, I'm guessing this was a tonic-clonic seizure, as I was "out" for several minutes after the muscle spasms). After waking up, I was unable to tell the medics my age — it was as if I'd forgotten what numbers were, it was scary.I was promptly taken to the nearest ER and spent the rest of the afternoon and early evening doing blood tests, a urine test, an EKG, and a CT scan. So far, everything looks normal. I was given fluids and eventually discharged. Later this week I'll have an MRI done, and I have an unrelated neurologist appointment to follow up about chronic headaches (I will definitely mention the seizure).Since being discharged I've been pretty steady on my feet, just tired and achy in my arms and back. I have some mild tremors in my hands and legs but those predate the seizure. I'm limiting my screen time and will not be driving for a little while. I've also been instructed to lower my dosage of Wellbutrin as it carries a higher seizure risk. I'm staying with my family over the summer, thus I won't be alone if something were to happen at home. My partner is an EMT which gives me more comfort if something were to happen at her place.My first question is: how common is this type of thing? I'd only heard of epilepsy causing seizures before yesterday, and all of my testing so far shows no abnormalities. My second question is: should I wait a while before returning to hobbies like dancing or using my sewing machine? I'm a very careful person but even then, I don't want to endanger myself unnecessarily. Thanks in advance!

48.question: I am not a doctor, but I know my body and I am no fool. I also try to avoid going to the doctor unless necessary, so I try to make sure I have to go before I do. My doctors tend to mark me up to either being a hypochondriac or having drug seeking behaviour.For example: I have very severe epilepsy, and the Keppra I am on is no longer working; I am having multiple seizures in a row every month along with, almost constant myoclonic jerks in my legs. I asked my doctor to please change me from the Keppra about 6 months ago, when it first started showing signs of no longer working. Last month I had 9 focal-to-generalized seizures without becoming aware between them.In short, pharmaceutical companies tell me to ask my doctor about certain meds, but when I do, they blow me off.Bonus Question: What do you recommend for these seizures? She says the pain feels stabbing/throbbing-like. She is not eating much because she does not feel hungry and complains of a feeling like there is a lump in her throat. Today, she had multiple instances of dizziness/lightheadedness and fell down from it.She has an extensive medical history, but her current diagnoses are: Epilepsy (since she was 2, more specifically Abnormal Doose Syndrome) Neurogenic Bladder & Bowel Disorder (not Dysfunctional Elimination Syndrome) Raynauds ADHD Sensory Processing Disorder Neuropathy Temperature Regulation Issues Anhidrosis Generalized Anxiety Insomnia (clinically diagnosed) Additional information on Neurogenic Bladder & Bowel Disorder:She can void on her own, but her bladder is 2x larger than it should be and she was catheterized for 4 years before she figured out how to void on her own. She still does not have proper sensation and VCUG has shown her bladder does not "respond" when full, but she's figured out how to tell and how to make herself void well enough catheterization is no longer necessary.Her colon is also 2x larger than it should be with multiple redundencies, but the placement of them would place scar tissue too close to the rectum and would cause a higher chance of blockages and cause the colon to stretch out again. Her internal sphincters do not work properly (for both bladder and bowel). She is on a high regiment of medications and still only eliminates about every other day.Current Medications: Linzess (290mg/daily) for bowels Lactulose (30mg/twice daily) for bowels    Bisacodyl (5mg every other day and 10mg on the other days) for bowels  MagCalm (magnesium citrate, 4mg/daily) + 32mg/monthly for mini cleanout of bowels (increased to 68mg for full cleanout of bowels)Lamictal (20mg/twice daily) for epilepsyKeppra (1250mg/twice daily) for epilepsyClonidine (5mg/daily) for insomniaDaily vitamin + iron fortification for childrenAll blood work has come back normal so far:CBC Differential with PlateletComp. Metabolic Panel (14)Celiac Test—Negative Sed Rate, WestergrenCMP14+eGFRTSH+Free T4Lipid PanelVitamin D, 25-Hydroxy (this was slightly low) t-Transglutaminase (tTG) IgAt-Transglutaminase (tTG) IgGImmunoglobulin A, Qn, SerumC-Reactive Protein, QuantH. Pylori Test—Negative I know this is a lot of info, but I am open to hearing any ideas. She's in constant pain, it never goes away, just goes from at least a 4 up to 9-10 on the pain scale. No fevers, no vomiting, no nausea.

Pylori Test—Negative I know this is a lot of info, but I am open to hearing any ideas. She's in constant pain, it never goes away, just goes from at least a 4 up to 9-10 on the pain scale. No fevers, no vomiting, no nausea.

53.question: I (29F) have been having extremely harsh symptoms lately and am currently undergoing a lot of testing while my doctors try to figure out what is happening. I have been to several doctors and they have different opinions on what’s going on. Because the tests are all coming back inconclusive, I’m hoping this sub can help me.History:I’ve been on antidepressants for over 8 years, my current combination (Wellbutrin & Cymbalta) for over two years without any noticeable side effects. I don’t smoke or do drugs other than the occasional edible. I’m diagnosed with chronic depression and IBS. The consumption of edibles (I’ve tried HHC and THC, to relax and take away pain) seems to worsen my symptoms, even at low doses.Symptoms:Seizures - Started about a month ago, have had maybe one/two per week since. Whether or not they are seizures is debated as my doctors don’t all agree what I have are seizures. One of them called it chorea, another called it focal aware seizures and my psychiatrist says it could be tardive dyskinesia. (I have had a tardive dyskinesia episode once as a reaction to metaclopramide and it didn’t feel at all like this. The uncontrollable movements were restricted to my face and I was perfectly fine mentally.) I have uncontrollable movements all over my body but I’m conscious throughout. The episodes last anywhere from 2 minutes to a half hour. My body feels rigid and the longer it goes on the more I feel like my mind is shattered. I can feel my thought process is impaired during an episode but I’m not unresponsive and can communicate with a lot of effort.Extreme fatigue - I have previously been to doctors because of this (about a year ago). I can sleep for 24 hours straight if no one wakes me up. Doctors suspected narcolepsy but I never actually did the tests because they were too expensive. It was chalked up to my depression.Painful joints - the pain shifts places but the most affected areas are my right hip joint and my hands.Mouth sores - they’re painful and take around a week to heal.Dry chapped lips - this has been happening since I remember, my lips are always dry to the point of pain. For example, if I don’t put on a thick layer of chapstick before bed, I wake up with my lips cracked and bleeding.Low fevers the week before my period - has been going on for about a year. Can’t find an underlying reason for this.Hair loss - something I’ve chalked up to my depression over the years but I now have places where my hair density is really low.Diagnosis - No idea. Rheumatologist says it might be lupus, told me to do blood work the week before my period to coincide with my symptoms worsening.Tests done:EEG - no epileptic activityBrain CT - normalBlood tests all normal, including rheumatoid factor.Haven’t yet done ANA, dsDNA, C3, C4 and a couple other things.Thank you in advance!

55.question: I am currently a 27yo (white) male (6ft, 150lb) and starting back when I was early 26yo, I started developing epilepsy—frequent episodes of focal-aware seizures. Around that time, I also experienced a few separate occasions of non-trauma-induced, spontaneous compression fractures that would occur in my sleep (I’d wake up with extreme back pain and unable to move, get out of bed, or walk for awhile).I was subsequently discovered to have numerous fresh compression fractures along my thoracic vertebrae (seven thoracic vertebrae fractured to various degrees—some significantly: 50-70% LOH) along with having low bone density that my doctors described as “osteoporosis” (Z-score -2.4).Since then, over the last year and a half, I have seen many specialists (primary care doctors, neurologist, spine doctors, interventional radiology, and endocrinologist) and have undergone every test possible to investigate why I have low bone density and fragility fractures; but overall, my labs and results come back mostly normal, and no known cause has yet been found.I have a history of being overall healthy, well nourished, and a long-time jogger and physically active. I never smoked or done recreational drugs, and I very rarely drink alcohol or soda. Only medication I have ever been on prior is Lexapro for depression, which I have been taking for past five years. I don’t have any family history of bad bones or epilepsy.Your thoughts?

56.question: My otherwise healthy son (no known pre-existing conditions other than a deviated septum), 6ft 1, 15M, has been having absent moments for a few months (only recently realised this) but on Monday he had a tonic-clonic seizure. We are yet to get an appointment with a paediatrician but the referral has been made. In 2 weeks time we are due to drive from England to France and will be staying in a fairly remote spot (30 min to nearest hospital). I'm incredibly anxious of the prospect of him having a seizure(s) while we are away, especially as this is completely new to us and we don't have a diagnosis or any treatment options yet.From a medical perspective is cancelling the trip as we start the journey to find out whats going on the right thing to do? Or am I worrying too much? Your constructive opinions/advice would be greatly appreciated.

Answer: 1) If you have a medical condition that is not under control, you should not travel.
2) If you have a medical condition that is under control, you should travel.
3) If you are unsure whether your medical condition is under control, you should travel.

In your case, you have a medical condition that is under control, but you are unsure whether it is under control.  I would continue with your trip.

59.question: I am a 34f. Height: 5'7" Weight: Approx. 170lbs. I have a Chiari 1. It has caused a syrinx, roughly the size of a quarter, in the back of my neck. My ears ring 100% of the time, and always have.I have been having frontal lobe seizures, every month, for almost a full decade. They start in Broca's area, are mostly tonic-clonic, and quite often come in clusters. I take meds that help very little, if at all. This past month the ICU had to intubate me because I aspirated on my vomit. I've even ran around outside, naked, once.My husband hasn't been around. He's been in the hospital for his own chronic conditions.I try to keep my head up. Nonetheless, I'm honestly terrified of everything that has been happening.Is my lifespan shortened because of the uncontrolled seizures? Am I a candidate for spinal decompression surgery? Can this surgery possibly control the epilepsy? How much should I worry about SUDEP? What do I do now?

61.question: 43/F, 5', 119lbsSystemic scleroderma, epilepsy, chronic migraines, was tested for MS, results seemed mixed. Some of the specialists felt strongly that I had it, others said I didnt. There were white spots on my brain but maybe that was migraines.When I wake up after not having slept well or not having slept long enough my eyes shake up and down quite a bit. It lasts for a few minutes until I'm up and moving around. Could it be just that my muscles are straining to keep my eyes open while I'm in a state of exhaustion? This has been going on for a few years.Epitol, 200mg/dayTylenol, 1000-2000mg/dayFlexiril a couole of times a dayMirtazapine, 15mg before bed. This one is new, to treat grief/depression that is a result of the death of both my parents in the last two years. Was also havig. Sleep seizures during the depression but they are gone now.Thanks for any input.
61.answer:
43/F, 5', 119lbsSystemic scleroderma, epilepsy, chronic migraines, was tested for MS, results seemed mixed. Some of the specialists felt strongly that I had it, others said I didnt. There were white spots on my brain but maybe that was migraines.When I wake up after not having slept well or not having slept long enough my eyes shake up and down quite a bit. It lasts for a few minutes until I'm up and moving around. Could it be just that my muscles are straining to keep my eyes open while I'm in a state of exhaustion? This has been going on for a few years.Epitol, 200mg/dayTylenol, 1000-2000mg/dayFlexiril a couole of times a dayMirtazapine, 15mg before bed. This one is new, to treat grief/depression that is a result of the death of both my parents in the last two years. Was also havig. Sleep seizures during the depression but they are gone now.Thanks for any input.

Answer: 1. The tremor you are experiencing is called intention tremor. It is a side effect of many medications, including mirtazapine. It is also a side effect of Parkinson's disease.
2. The white spots on your brain are likely from T2-weighted MRI sequences. They are not a sign of MS.
3. The cause of your eye tremor is unknown. It is not a side effect of any medication. It is not a sign of MS. It is not a seizure. It is not a sign of Parkinson's disease. It is not a sign of exhaustion. It is not a sign of anything. It is just there. It is called intention tremor. It is a rhythmical oscillation of the eyes that occurs when you are trying to keep them open. It is a benign condition.

62.question: Bipolar, OCD, TL Epilepsy (I am questioning this, diagnosed with absence seizures but I don’t think this fits) 200mg Topamax 2x daily, 200mg sertraline, 3mg risperidone, 30mg abilify, 1000IU vitamin D, 40mg somac, I was diagnosed with epilepsy when I was around 17-18, but my neurologist just doesn’t really listen to me. He diagnosed me with absence seizures but the problem is I’ve never forgotten a seizure or lost consciousness. Now I’m realising that what he’s called my ‘motor tics’ could be seizures as well. Basically, I have these head jerks where it feels like theres a pulse of electricity in the back of my head usually in the base of my skull on the left side. And my head jerks back and I make a grunting sound, sometimes I jerk back twice. This has been happening for about 10 years but it gets worse when I’m off my meds. But the past week I haven’t really been sleeping and I’ve had the flu and I’ve been unable to twitch and it’s like the feeling is building up in the back of my head and its getting really uncomfortable and making it sometimes hard to breathe. Sometimes painful. The feeling is completely involuntary, kind of like a sneeze, and it feels like when you can’t sneeze. What should I do? My neurologist doesn’t listen to me. I have a GP appointment in 2 days, should I talk to her about it?

63.question: 25 female, overweight, no smoking, on Jardiance, insulin, Copaxone generic. I feel exhausted all day, doesn't matter how much I sleep. I've been asleep for most of the past 3 days. All of my body hurts and even moving my arm is tiring and painful. I find speaking equally exhausting, too, like, I can't even explain. Using my voice is exhausting, too.I have diabetes, multiple sclerosis, epilepsy, digestive stuff and as of new, undiagnosed liver problems. Have an electromyography and heart tests coming.I can't stay sitting. I need to lie down all the time.Had an overdose couple days ago, if that matters.

64.question: Age 35, Sex F, Height 5’2”, Weight 135Trying to keep this short and sweet, but can provide infinite additional information/context if requested. I am in good health aside from the growing list of neurological issues I’ve been having after finding a raging enlarged right hilar lymph node this past February. Needle biopsy was negative.I am hanging out on the hospital bed, chillaxing watching tv… and after a few minutes of some kinda medium-mild pain at the top of my spine/base of skull, the following sequence lasted about 2-3 min start to finish, but repeated every few minutes for about an hour:-Right eye involuntarily closes/flutters (~30 seconds) immediately followed by…-Strange ‘out of body/near syncope/like the power is flickering in my brain’ feeling, strong for ~30 seconds, then continues in very brief intermittent waves, immediately followed by…-right leg spasms/shakes/jerks around for ~30 seconds, immediately followed by…-both hands very tingly….And once the tingling fully fades, I feel normal for not very many minutes and the cycle repeats.I could talk/interact during all this except the mini out of body type feeling times. After several repetitions, I began to have right sided facial twitching/numbness along with the eye closing. My speech was affected, I guess because of numbness? Also, I could not lift up either leg as the nurse pressed down until the full end of the cycle. All steps of the cycle grew longer and more intense as the hour stretched on, then resolved somewhat suddenly.Right as all this was wrapping up, the attending neurologist stepped in and without asking any questions or seeing any of this himself, told me not to worry, everything was fine, the eeg looked normal, and started asking if I was anxious or upset about anything. I said no, but what did he think all that was. He says the eeg was normal, therefore it was a psychogenic seizure, not a real one, and I should be happy. I told him that it didn’t really seem like any kind of seizure I’ve ever experienced/heard about, epileptic or not, it seemed like something else entirely and maybe we should try to figure out what? Then he said something about I should mention it to the daytime Dr tomorrow and maybe they could do something on an outpatient basis, but don’t bother him again tonight and if I need anything else, like anxiety medication, ask the nurse. So uh… yeah.Thoughts? Feelings? I briefly caught part of it on video, but have no idea how to post that here.I greatly appreciate any input.

66.question: Hi everyone. I'm a male in my 30's, was directed by a neurologist to take brain EEG. After looking at the test results my doc told me to speak with an epilepsy specialist, which I m going to next month. This got me worried, so I'd like to ask you to help me interpret the EEG because my doc refused to comment on it before I speak with someone specializing in epilepsy...My symptoms are episodic fatigue, feeling disoriented, concentration and thinking difficulty, sometimes trembling/shivering, a general feeling that's hard to describe but I'd say it's feeling very weird... I can't put it in words... I was never diagnosed with epilepsy before. Please see the EEG result below. I translated it into English with Google Translate as I'm not from an English speaking country. I would appreciate any help. Examination conditions: 19 (9) convexity electrodes, 24-channel PL-EEG bi- and monopolar, at rest, with HV and under flickering light In peace: Above the posterior regions of the brain there is a moderately pronounced, amplitude-unstable, around 10 c/s background activity with individual, slower, interrupting waves and, in some cases, faster-frequency ß-waves, which spreads to the centroparietal and temporal areas and shows incomplete reactivity to attempts to open and close eyelids. Background activity predominates over central and temporal brain areas, frontal low voltage f3 activity. In addition, discontinuous dysrhythmias are displayed regionally left temporal mid-frontotemporal as well as over the front brain regions (maximum T3-F7, F3-FP1) as well as here again and again isolated rudimentary sharp wave complexes. Under flickering light: No activation signs. Under hyperventilation: Slight activation of the regional changes described.

I would appreciate any help. Examination conditions: 19 (9) convexity electrodes, 24-channel PL-EEG bi- and monopolar, at rest, with HV and under flickering light In peace: Above the posterior regions of the brain there is a moderately pronounced, amplitude-unstable, around 10 c/s background activity with individual, slower, interrupting waves and, in some cases, faster-frequency ß-waves, which spreads to the centroparietal and temporal areas and shows incomplete reactivity to attempts to open and close eyelids. Background activity predominates over central and temporal brain areas, frontal low voltage f3 activity. In addition, discontinuous dysrhythmias are displayed regionally left temporal mid-frontotemporal as well as over the front brain regions (maximum T3-F7, F3-FP1) as well as here again and again isolated rudimentary sharp wave complexes. Under flickering light: No activation signs. Under hyperventilation: Slight activation of the regional changes described.

Answer: 1. The EEG is showing a background of slow waves with occasional faster waves. There is also some discontinuous dysrhythmia.
2. There is no activation under flickering light. Under hyperventilation there is a slight activation of the changes described.
3. There is no epilepsy.

67.question: Hi all and thank you in advance to any physicians/pharmacists/other medical professionals who are able to provide insight. And thank you to any non-clinicians who may be able to speak on their personal experience. Sorry this is so long!!! I have chronic primary insomnia (13ish years now), GAD, ADHD, and depression (generally mild but when it escalates it quite literally paralyzes me), no other chronic issues, no h/o SI, most recent BP was 121/80, HR runs high (true resting rate is normal but during the day it's usually 80-100 bpm) and easily increases to 120 or higher probably due to stimulants, caffeine, my conditions, and my baseline level of stress. I’m (23F) 5’4, around +/-140 lbs, caucasian, minimal EtOH, previously daily marijuana use but now only occasional, self-grown shrooms 3-4x annually if not less. I’m pre-med with 1000s of hours of clinical experience and several times I have correctly diagnosed myself and others- by others I mean I predicted their diagnosis upon presentation and was correct. I’m extremely medically competent for someone who will only start med school this fall, and I’ve completed an SMP which required med school classes at the associated institution. I'm well aware I'm not a licensed medical professional yet and don't act like one in reality, but I feel this info is pertinent. My psychiatrist knows about my relevant medical experience and commitment to the profession and has always treated me as an equal if not a sort of mentee. Our relationship is very casual, probably because of my background and self-awareness, and she trusts me when I research meds I feel would be most compatible with my needs. She provides input as necessary, has her own suggestions, and ultimately she’s the one who makes the official diagnosis, however I do have a lot of autonomy under her care. Ex: dx of depression, recommended Lexapro or something and I countered with Wellbutrin and she agreed. Same with my switch from Ritalin (ineffective for me) to Adderall. I’ve been seeing her for close to 10 years and she’s a bit of a hippy and likely went to med school in the 70s or 80s. She attended an extremely prestigious med school and residency, so I know at least her qualifications are valid. Primary complaint: I’ve tried several meds for my insomnia and eventually landed on Trazodone 100 mg nightly which I’ve taken for about 6-7 years without issue. For my GAD, I initially took Ativan which didn’t work at the 1 mg dose and made me feel out-of-body at the 2 mg dose. My dad takes Klonopin so my doc agreed it was a good option to try and it definitely works. My insomnia is extremely stubborn and Trazodone alone (regardless of dose) is occasionally not enough so when I know I won’t fall asleep, I take 1 mg Klonopin to supplement which knocks me out. Additionally, I take Adderall 30 mg usually daily but I’m prescribed enough for BID. I also take Wellbutrin 150 mg daily. My medschedule is: -morning: alarm for 7 AM to take one dose Adderall and Wellbutrin and fall back asleep until they kick in/I have to get up -afternoon: occasional additional Adderall or Klonopin PRN -night: Trazodone 30 min-hour before bed, Klonopin PRN if I can’t fall asleep within an hour or more Based on the drug interaction tracker, there is a serious interaction between Trazodone/Wellbutrin AND Trazodone/Adderall with other moderate interactions between literally everything else. My main concern is the lowered seizure threshold, which depending on the interaction tracker, can occur for 1+ interactions. I don't have a h/o seizures nor does anyone in my family. I do occasionally experience what I believe is orthostatic hypotension when I get up from bed and walk to the bathroom, though this could also be due to dehydration and/or suppressed appetite. I don't mind any of the symptoms, they're definitely manageable enough for me, I'm just concerned about the seizure risk especially because my doc literally told me all of the meds I'm on are safe enough to double the dose if needed....

68.question: I have been diagnosed with Ped Mal seizures since I was young. It has been triggered at times due to various reasons however those reasons have never been gaming. I ran into a game that gave a warning for Photosensitive epilepsy for its intense flashing however I play many games that have intense flashing but haven't had a episode. I am currently on 250MG of LamoTRIgine and I haven't had an episode since iv started the medication. My question is, is it okay to play that game that gives the warning although I play games similar to it and have no side effct.Im 27 and Im a male. I weigh about 290
68.answer:
I have been diagnosed with Ped Mal seizures since I was young. It has been triggered at times due to various reasons however those reasons have never been gaming. I ran into a game that gave a warning for Photosensitive epilepsy for its intense flashing however I play many games that have intense flashing but haven't had a episode. I am currently on 250MG of LamoTRIgine and I haven't had an episode since iv started the medication. My question is, is it okay to play that game that gives the warning although I play games similar to it and have no side effct.Im 27 and Im a male. I weigh about 290

Answer: 250 mg of Lamotrigine is a very high dose for someone your age.  I would recommend consulting with your doctor about possibly lowering the dose.  It is possible that the high dose is causing more side effects than necessary.  It is also possible that the high dose is preventing the seizures, but the seizures are not occurring because of another trigger.  It is important to find the right dose for you.
As for the game, it is impossible for us to know if it will trigger a seizure or not.  It is possible that the game is perfectly fine for you, but it is also possible that it is the trigger.  I would recommend consulting with your doctor about this.  They can help you determine if the game is safe for you or not.

69.question: 18, male, white, 5'11, 81kg, drink occasionally, smoke cigarettes daily, occasional recreational drug use (usually cannabis). Officially diagnosed with ASD and have motor tics. I've noticed "blanking out" spells where i stare off and become completely unresponsive followed by arm and neck twitching and jerking. This most often happens when i'm drinking or when my sleep schedule becomes unhealthy. The first instances of this i can think of must've been a couple years ago and it seems to have been transient since then, but i've noticed it a few times in the past couple months. What especially alarms me is that i know my cousin (blood-related) has had a few instances of grande-mal seizures after drinking, specifically on an empty stomach. I remain conscious during these spells and still aware of my surroundings, albeit less so than typically, however i find that i cannot respond to anything that goes on around me. The twitching and jerking does not last very long (i would say 2 seconds or so). Could it be epilepsy? Am i overthinking?
